Hi Barb...remember me?...I started TX the same day you did so I'm right here with you.I don't have answers for you but I can tell you what's going on with me at this point...  As far as the red bumps, I started getting them weeks ago on my back and now they have spread to my chest and, yes, they itch like crazy.  I have been doing pretty good about keep the itch to a low burn with Aveeno products, including the hydrocortisone cream.I also have had problems with the shakes or internal tremors and, in fact, I had my monthly appt with the NP on a day when they were particularly bad and she didn't even seem to care about it at all.  I finally told her that the jitters were starting to make me crazy so she gave me some Xanax (I tried ADs earlier and they made me sick) and the Xanax seems to help a lot though I only seem to need to take one or two a week now.My hair is also thinning and that just started.  I had my hair trimmed the other day and my hair dresser told me she saw a thinning spot that I hadn't yet noticed.I've had chest pain too but I think I've traced it to severe muscle fatigue in my back/shoulder area that radiates to my chest when I'm tired.  I've been using a heat pad and I also ordered a Homedic massager that I hope will help (once I get it).As far as your blood sugar, a normal "fasting" blood sugar is 110 or under - I think.  I'm sure there are more knowledgeable people on here that can help with that.  If you were checking your BS, do you already have diabetes or were you just checking with someone else's equipment or was that a test from the doc's lab?  If it was from the doc, did he/she have anything to say about it?I have also had diarrhea (in fact, had it today) and the color sounds a lot like what you describe.So, hang in there Barbie...I know it's not fun but I truly believe we can get through this.  I totally understand your feeling of wanting to quit...I've had days like that too...but that's why the rest of us will all chime in and tell you:  "Stick with us, Barb, you can do it...there will be better days!"

What is a fasting blood sugar (glucose) test?Measures the amount of sugar (glucose) in your blood after you fast for at least eight hours or overnight.What's normal?A normal range is 70 to 100 milligrams of glucose per deciliter of blood (mg/dL) or 3.9 to 5.6 millimoles per liter (mmol/L). What level suggests prediabetes?A level of 100 to 125 mg/dL (5.6 to 6.9 mmol/L) indicates impaired fasting glucose — commonly known as prediabetes. To confirm the diagnosis, your doctor may repeat the fasting blood sugar test several days to a week later.What level suggests prediabetes?A level of 100 to 125 mg/dL (5.6 to 6.9 mmol/L) indicates impaired fasting glucose — commonly known as prediabetes. To confirm the diagnosis, your doctor may repeat the fasting blood sugar test several days to a week later.What level suggests type 1 or type 2 diabetes?A level of 126 mg/dL (7 mmol/L) or higher is consistent with either type 1 or type 2 diabetes. To confirm the diagnosis, your doctor may repeat the fasting blood sugar test on another day. If your test results are 126 mg/dL (7 mmol/L) or higher twice in a row after at least eight hours of fasting, you may have diabetes. Further testing may be needed to determine whether you have type 1 diabetes or type 2 diabetes.Have you had your thyroid checked?  Is you HGB within acceptable levels?  Riba affects everyone differently.  Sounds like you are having a strong reaction but it's temporary, when you complete tx, hopefully your skin will return to normal. We don't get through this treatment unscathed.  Many side effects and we just have to have patience.  Quitting now means no chance of eradicating the virus.  That means at some point in your life you will be dealing with a whole new series of problems that won't be reverseable.  Irritation at the injection site in not uncommon.  My tummy area where I've been injecting has turned light brown and stays that way.  Talk with your doctor, make sure he knows what you are experiencing. There are many ways to minimize the side effects.  Good LuckTrinity

If you're getting tremors in your hands as in you notice your hands are shaking and your equilibrium is a little off, ask your doctor to run a thyroid test.  It might not be your thyroid at play but could be, not uncommon for this to develop on treatment.  I started to get tremors in my hands and I wrote it off at first as another side of treatment only it got progressively worse and my equilibrium started being off and my doctor immediately had me tested for thyroid and I came back as hyperthyroid.  I'd ask about it.  It's too bad that your NP writes off sides like that as anxiety when there could be an underlying medical reason for it.  Good luck.Trish
